learningContent.title: Testing the DITA Open Toolkit installation

lcInstruction.p: Now that you have installed the DITA Open Toolkit and the required JAVA Development Kit and set up your folder structure, you're ready to run your first test build. Follow the instructions below to generate a sample PDF file using the DITA OT. Separate instructions are provided for PC and Mac users.
lcInstruction.note: These instructions only apply to 2.x versions of the DITA Open Toolkit.

task.title: Running a DITA OT test build on a PC

step.cmd: Type cd to navigate to the OT folder
Type the following string of commands into the command window to run the DITA OT:

info.p: bin\dita specifies that you are generating DITA output

-i tells the DITA OT the name and filepath of the DITA map or file that needs to be transformed into output.To enter the filepath and filename without typing it, navigate to the file on your system, click on the file's icon, and drag the icon directly into the command window.

-f tells the DITA OT which transtype, or output transformation type, to use. The transtype value indicates whether the output type should be PDF, HTML, webhelp, or any other format.For the purpose of this exercise, you have entered pdf2 as the transtype to generate output from the DITA OT's default PDF plugin.

-o tells the DITA OT where to store the generated output. If no output directory is specified, the DITA OT will place the output into its default "out" folder. To specify a directory without typing it, navigate to the folder on your system, click on the folder's icon, and drag the icon directly into the command window.
-v tells the DITA OT to display the command log as it generates the output. Typing this command is optional, but it is useful to watch the DITA OT run in realtime to help troubleshoot errors.

step.cmd: Press ENTER to run the DITA Open Toolkit.
step.info: Because you entered the optional -v command, you will see a log of the DITA OT's build process in realtime displayed in the command window.

step.cmd: Look in the output folder you specified to see your generated output. You should see a file called [filename].pdf.
